body.div:
Vol. II
Chap I
"Itis with difficulty that I remember
the æraof my cr being.All the events of
that period appear confused & indistinct.
I know only that I felt a strange A strange
sensation sea seized me and a it appeared
I saw, felt heardand smeltat the same
timeand it was indeeda long time be
fore I learned to distinguish between the
various
operations of my various senses. By degrees
I remembera stronger light pressed upon
my nerves and so that I was obliged to close
my eyes. Darkness then came over me
and troubled me.–But hardly had I felt
this when (byopening my eyesas I now suppose)
the light poured in upon me again–I walked
andI believedescended; but presently Ifound
a great
difference alteration
in my sensations; before
dark opaque bodies had surrounded me,
impervious to my touch or sight – andI
now found that I could wander on at liberty
with no obstacles which I could not either
surmount or avoid–The light be became
^
more &
more opressiveto me andthe heat wearying
me as I walkedI sought a place where I could
perceive
recieve
shade. This was the forest near Ingolstadt,
andhere by the side of a brook I lay weary
for some hours
^
resting from my fatigue untillI felt tormented by
hunger and thirst. This roused me from my nearly
dormant stateand I ate some berries
which I found
^
hanging
on the treesor lying on
the ground –I slaked my thirst bythe
brookand then again lying down Iwas
overcome by sleep – ; Itwas dark when I
awoke,I felt cold alsoand half frightened
^
as it were instinctively on seein finding myself so desolate.
Before I had quitted your appartment
on a sensation of coldI had covered my
selfwith some clothes,but these were
not in sufficientto secure me from the
dw dews of night. I was a poor helpless
miserable wretch—I knew no & could
distinguish no nothing but
felt
^
feeling
pain
invade me on all sides and I sat down
and wept.
Soona gentle light stole over the
heavensand gave me a sensation of pleasure
I started up, and beheld a radiant form
rise am from among the trees.I gazed with
a kind of wonder –It moved slowly;but
it enlightened my path,and I again
went out in search of berries. I was still
coldwhen on the ground under one of the
trees I found a huge cloakwith which I–
covered myself, and sat down onthe ground.
No distinct ideas occupied my mindall was
confused and I felt the light, and hunger
and thirstand darkness; innumerable
sounds rung in my earsand on all sides
various scents saluted me;the only object
that I could distinguish was the bright
moonand I fixed my eyes
i o n th that with
pleasure. Severalchanges of day and night
passedand the orb of night had greatly
lessenedwhen I began to distinguish my
sensations
^
from each other– .I
first saw
dis gradually saw plainly
the clear stream
that supplied me with drinkand the
gre
trees that
covered
^
shaded
me with their foliage.
I was delighted when I first discovered
that a pleasant sound that
which often
delighte saluted my earsproceeded
from the throats of son the little
anih winged
a m ni mals who often intercepted the light
from my eyes. I began also to see an
with forms greater accuracythe forms
that surrounded meand to perceive
the boundaries of the radiant light which
overspeaed my dwelling canopied me.–some
times I tried to imitate the pleasant songs of
the birdsbut was unable—Sometimes I
also wished to express my sensations in
my own modebut the uncouth and innarticu
late sound which broke from me which frightened
me into silence again.
Themoon had dissapearedfrom the night, &
againwith a lessened form it shewed itself
again while I still remained in the forest.
My
ideas
^
sensations
wereby this timebecome distinct
&
^
my mind
received every day aditional ones
^
ideas. My eyes
became accustomed to the lightand to
perceive objects in their right forms; I distin
guished the
insect insect from the herb, andby de
grees one herb from a another –I found
that the sparrow uttered none but harsh
notes and
but
whilst
that
^
those of
the blackbird were sweet
and enticing. I had le one daywhen I was
oppressed by coldI found a fire that
had been left by some wandering beg
gars and was over comewith delight
.
X
X
at the warmth
which I ex-
periencedfrom
it.
In my joy I thrust my hand into the
live embersbut quickly drew it away with a cry
in
of
pain–How strange, I thought, that the
same cause should at once produce
such
delicious and such
u
opp opposite
effects –Iexamined the materials of the
fire, & to my joy found it to be wood –
I quickly collected some branchesbut
they were wetand would not burn.
I was pained at thisand sat still
watching the o p perationof the fire.
The wet wood I had placed near the heat
became dy dry dried,
and itself became became
hot
inflamed.
I reflected on this, andby touching
the various branchesI discovered the cause
and busied myself in collecti on ng
a great
deal quantity
of woodthat I might dry itand
have a pel plentiful supply
o of fire. When night
came onand
^
brought with it sleep,I was in the greatest
fear lest my fire should be extinguished
I covered it carefully with try dry wood
and leaves& then placed upon that wet
branchesand thenspreading my cloakI la
on the ground I
& sunk into sleep. I was morning
when I Itwas morning when I awoke& my
first care was to visit the fire –Iuncovered
itand th a gentle breeze quickly fanned it
into a flameI observed this alsoand contri
ved a fan of brancheswhich roused the
embers when thywere nearly extinguished.
When night again cameI foundwith plea
sure that the fire gave light as well
as heat and I often and the discovery of this
element was useful to me also in my food–
for I found some of offals that the travel
lers had left had been roastedand tasted
much more savoury than the berries
I gathered;I tried thereforeto dress my food
in the same manner, placing them
on the live embers–I found that the
berries were spoiled by this o p peration
and the nuts much improved. Food
howeverbecame very scarceand I often
spent aday searching in vain for a
few acorns to assuage the pangs of hunger.
When I found thisresolved to quit the place
whichI had hitherto inhabited &to seek for
a place one
where the few wants I expe
rienced would be more easily satisfied.
In this emigrationI
extremely exceedingly
lamented the
loss of my fire–Ihad obtained it by by strange
meansand knew not how to re produceit. by myself
This
this deficiency obtained myserious consideration for
several hoursbut I was obliged to leave it
relinquish all
attemptsto
supply it, and wrapp
i ngmyself up in my cloak
I struck across the wood towards the
setting sun –I passed three days in these
ramblesand at length discovered the
open country –A great fall of snow had
taken place the night beforeand the
fields were of one uni n form whitethe
appearrancewas disconsolateand I
found my feet chilled by the cold dab
damp
^
substance that covered the
ground – Itwas about seven in
the morningand I longed to obtain food
and shelter.At length I perceived in a
small hutwhich had
b doubtless been
built for the convenience of
the
some sheph e ard.This was a new sight
to meand I examined the stu struc
ture
of it with great curiosity.
and
finding the door openI entered. An old
man sat it in it, near a fire on
over
which he was preparing his breakfast
he turned of on hearing a noise & on
and perceiving me shrieked loudly and quiting
the hutran across the fields with
a speed little of which his debilitated form
hardly appeared capable . of
His flight
somewhat surprised me –but I was
inchanted withthe appearance of the
hut.Here the snow and rain could not
penetrate –the ground was dry and wind
expelled and it
appeared presented
to me then
as heavenly and divine exquisite &di
vine a retreat as Pandemoniumappeared
to the
tr dominionsof Hell . after thier suffocationin the
lake of
fire. I greedily
devoured the rem m n antsof the shepherds
breakfastwhich consisted of bread, cheese,
milk& rhenish wine; the latter of which
howeverI did not like. Thenovercome
by fatigue I laydown among some straw
&fell asleep.
Itwas noon when I awoke andallured
by the warth warmth of the sunI deter
mined to recommence my travels–& wrapping
dep
depositing
the
rest remains
of the herds bre peasants break
fast in a wallet I found, I proceeded
across the fields for several hours, untill
at sunset I
came to arrived at
a village. How mira
culous did this appear.The hutsthe neater
cottages& stat
^
e lier housesengaged my
admiration by turns–The vegetables in the
garden s allured me andthe milk and
cheese that I saw placed at s the windows
of some of the cottages —
allured me—
One of the best of
these I entered–but I had hardly placed
my foot
inside within
the doorbefore the
children shriekedand one of the
child
ren women fainted,the village was roused
some fled,—someattacked me untill
grievously bruised by
sticks
^
stones
and all
many other kinds of missile weaponI
escaped to the open country and fear
fullytook refuge in a low
hut hovel –quite
bareand making a wretched appearance
after the pal l acesI had beheld in the
village.– This
hut hovel however adjoineda
cottage of a neat & pleasant appearance,
butafter my late
^
dearly
bought experience
I dared not enter it. My place of refuge
X
was the tool house and had not been
was not used for by the inhabitants of the ad
joining dwelling and was entirely shut
out from view by a pigstye on one
side and a dunghill & small s pool
on the another – the two others were
formed by the wall of the cottage. Here
then I retreated and lay down happy to have
found a shelter from the inclemency
of the season & still more from the
barbarity of man
___________________________
was constructed of wood,
& but
so lowthat
I could with difficulty sit upright in
it. The f earth No wood however
was placed on the earthwhich formed
the floor of the cottagebut it was dry
and although the wind entered by
innumerable chinksI found it an
agreable assylumfrom the snow
& rain
Chap. 2
Assoon as morning dawnedI crept from
my assylum to that I might view the
adjacent cottageand discover if I could
remain in the kennel thatI had found.
It was situated
at
^
against
the back of the cottage
and
^
surrounded
on
its
^
the
open the
sides which were exposed
by a pigstye& –c r l ear poolof waterone
part was openand by that I had crept
inbut now with stones and wood I cover
edevery crevice with stones & wood by which I might be
discovered ^
yet in such a manner
that I couldmove the n m
on an occasion
to pass out;all the light I enjoyed came
through the styeand that was suffi
cientfor me.
Havingthus arranged my dwelling&
spr carpeted it with clean straw, I retired
for I saw the figure of a man
in at
a distance
and I feared remembered
but
too well my treatment the night
before not to trust myself in his
power. I had first howeverprovided
for my sustenance for that day by mean
by a loaf of bro coarse breadwhich I pur
loinedand a cup
w by with
which I could take
drin g k
more conveniently than from my
hand and
of the pure water which flowed by my
house retreat – but
t T he f
l oor of that being
was a little raised
it
^
so that it was kept
^
perfectly
dryand by
its vicinity to the chimney of the
kitchen fire of the cottage it was
tolerably warm.
And
b B eingthus provided
I determinedto reside in this hovel
untill o something should occur which
might alter my determination. It
was indeed a paradisecompared to
the blea c kforest, my former residence,
and the
ir rain dropping leaves
^
branches
^
& the dank earth .I ate
my breakfast with pleasureand was
about to remove a plank to procure
myself a little waterwhen I heard
a step andlooking through a small
chink abeheld a young creature
with a pail on her headpassing
before my hovel. The girl was youn
g
and of gentle demænourunlike what
I have since found Cottagers and farm
houseservants to be –Yet she was mean
ly dressed –a blue coarse
^
blue
petticoat and a
linen jacket being her only garb on her fair hair
was plaitedbut not adorned; she looked patient
yet sad. She passed aw away butin a quarter
of an hour returned, be bearing the pailwhich
was now partly filled with milk. As she walked
alongseemingly incommoded by the burthen
a young man met herwhose countenance
expressed a deeper desponc
e ns des ces ly; than her
uttering a few
words sounds
with ain an air of
melancholyhe took the pail from her head
and bore it intothe cottage himself. She
followed wiping dry my her tears whi ,and they
diasppeared –Presently I saw the young man
againwith some tools in his handcross the
field oppositethe cottageand the girl was
also busied someti n m esin and som the cottage
and sometimes in the yard where she fe t d
some ck chickens. and after some hours While
I examinedmy dwellingI discoveredthat part
of the cottage window had formerly occupied
a cornerof it pu but the panes had n been
filled up with wood. In one of these was
a small & allmostimperceptible h chink,
through which
howev the eye could just
pene a t rate; and looking in I behe sa w throthis chink
a
small room was visible, whitewashed
^
&
cleanbut very
bare of furniture & in co one cornernear
a small fire I saw
^
beheld
sate
an old man sitting leaning
his head on his hand – in a disconslate atti
tude — X
his hair
was grey
The young girl was co occupied in
arranging the cottage and
but presently
when that was
done she took somthingout of the a drawer
which employed her hands and
^
& sat down beside the o
the old
man who taking up an instur instrumentbegan
to playand to produce soundssweeter than
the voice of the thrush or nightingale. This chapter is too short
It was a lovely sighteven to mepoor
whec wretchwho had never beheld aught
beautiful before.
his the
silver hairs&
benevolent countenance
^
of
the more aged inhabit cottager
won my reverence
while
^
the
gentle manners of the girl enticed
my love. He played a sweet mournful
airwhich I percieveddrew tears from
the eyes of
the gen amiable gir l
^
his
you amiable companion
till her
of which the old man took
^
no
notice of it untill
she sobbed audibly –He the then pronounced
a few soundsand the poor creatureleaving
her workknelt at his feethe rasied her
and smiled with such grace kindness &
lovethat I felt my own hard nerves
move and I was obliged to withdraw from
naturethey were a
nature
mixture of pain & pleasure;such as I had never experienced
my the hole. Presently the young ma
either from the hunger or cold,
orfrom or warmth or foodand I
withdrew
from my station withdrew
unable to
bear these new
these
emotio
ns
emotions
Soonafter this the young man returned
bearing on his sholdersa load load of wood
the r girl met him at the door & helped
to relieve him of his burden and took
taking some of itinto the fire cottage
placed it on the fire;
& then she and the
youth went apart into a
nok nook
of the cottage
and he shewedher a large loaf and a piece
of cheese .— She seemed pleasedand went
into the garden for soomeroots & plants
which she placed in waterand then upon
the fire–.She
then afterwards
continued her work &
whilst
the young man went into the pa garden
and appeared busily employed in digging & pul
pulling up roots– –Afterhe had been employed
thus about hal an hourthe young woman
joined him, & they returned tothe cottage
together – Theold man in the mean time
hadbeen pe
^
n sive buton the approach
of
the others
^
his companions
he assumed a
pen more
cheerful
air, and they sat down to eat. They quickly
finished the
ir meal
^
was quickly dispatched;
the young woman was
again occupied in arranging the cottagethe
old man walked before the doorin the
sun for a few minutes ,leaning on the arm of the you ng th
man
Nothing could exceed in beauty the contrast
between these two love excl excellent
creaturesOne was old, with silver hairs
and a countenance beaming with bene
volence& love;the younger was sli m ght
and graceful in his fu figureand
his feautureswere moulded with the
finest
simetry symmetry –yet his eyes & attitude
expressed the utmost sadness and despon
dencency—The old man returned to the
cottage; and the youthwith tools different
from those which he had used in the morning,
directed his steps across the fields– Night
quickly shut in butto my extreme won
derI found that the cottagers had a
means of prolonging lightby the use of tapers
and was pleasedto findthat end setting
of the sun did not put an end I had to
the pleasure I experienced in watching
the
my human neighbours . –Inthe evening
the young girl and her companion
were employed in various occupations;
that
which I did not then understand,& the
old man again took that instru
mentwhich produced th o e se
divine
sounds that had enchanted me in
the morning.
and
w W hen So soon as
he had finish
-edthe youth began,–not to play , –but
he to
utter ed sounds whichwere monoto
nous and and
far from neither resembling
the harmony
of the old mansinstrument orthe
songs of the birdsI since found that
he read aloud , but at that time I knew nothing of the
science of words or letters. a
t that
time . The family soonextinguished
their lightsand retired, as I conjectured,
to sleep . rest
